text: I'm a firm believer that everybody
should have a great biscuit recipe in
their repertoire and so today I thought
why not share mine with you I'm making a
cheddar chive biscuit three tablespoons
of minced chives are going to give great
flavor to this biscuit but you could use
other herbs if you wanted to just base
it on whatever it is that you love so
that's about three tablespoons I'm not
going to need that right away it's a
pretty large recipe you need four cups
of all-purpose flour I like to sort of
stir my flour up a little bit then scoop
and level to that add two tablespoons of
baking powder biscuits do require quite
a bit of lemon or more than your average
and then 1/2 a teaspoon of baking soda
and one in 3/4 teaspoons of salt pulse
that together and then add one and a
half sticks of unsalted butter cold and
cut into small pieces one and a half
cups of grated sharp cheddar cheese and
then your 3 tablespoons of chives you
want to pulse this until the butter is
the size of small peas and smaller
it's the pieces of butter that are left
kind of large in the mixture
like don't over profit you're not going
to have sleepy biscuits that looks good
add your buttermilk it's one and a half
cups of cold buttermilk and pulse till
everything combines don't over mix your
dough because you're going to need it on
a lightly floured surface after it comes
out of the mixer you don't want it
overworked so I know I sound like a
broken record but I really mean it with
biscuits it's extra extra extra
important knead it once or twice just so
all the little extra bits that are
flying all over the board get
incorporated I can feel that all my
ingredients were nice and cold which is
also super important when making both
biscuits and pie crust the colder that
your butter is the more it will hold its
shape when it goes into the hot oven and
then as its melts it makes pockets and
that's what makes flakiness and if all
your other ingredients are cold it helps
keep the butter cold roll your dough out
about 3/4 of an inch thick recorder
tarnish let me use my handy-dandy ruler
looks about right okay so once it's
three quarters of an inch thick get a
baking pan and a two and three-quarter
inch biscuit or cookie cutter to cut out
your biscuits and cut as close together
as possible so you have as few scraps as
possible you can put these directly onto
a baking sheet on butter there's plenty
of butter in your biscuits already so I
have some scraps here that I don't want
to waste so Pat them together don't even
reroll them just sort of press them
together and you should be able to get
at least three more out of it you should
get between twelve and fourteen biscuits
from this recipe
that's a little bit crowded actually so
I'm going to divide these between two
trades there we go bake your biscuits at
450 degrees until they're puffed and
golden and cooked through about 15
minutes they're puffed and golden mmm

savoring delicious cheese each IV
